title: Could a black hole still grow if it consumes nothing but light? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes Henri, a physical black hole can grow in mass and radius just by ‘consuming’ only light, but very very very slowly. The received light adds only a little bit of energy to the black hole that cannot escape afterwards, so the total amount of energy increases. That is why black holes always keep on growing, because there is always light to ‘consume’, if nothing else is around. Nothing can escape a black hole, nothing. That increased energy of the physical black hole makes is more massive (energetic) and therefore the physical radius will also increase. Needless to say that the almost meaningless Event Horizon or Schwarzschild radius of the non-physical but popular definition of a black hole will also grow, but that meaningless growth is so extremely small, relative to that meaningless relative big EH / S radius for most black holes, that its hardly meaningful to mention.

A black hole would not grow if nothing by light fell into it. Light is electromagnetic energy and energy does not take up space it simply occupies space where anything else could occupy at the same time. So light does not contribute to growth of inorganic things. Light does contribute to the growth of organic organisms on earth but not inorganic things like black holes. There is evidence that a black hole grows whenever it merges with another black hole. But after reaching a certain size limit they seem to stop growing.

Could a black hole still grow if it consumes nothing but light? Yes, I’m sure of it. Light is a form of energy, and so is matter. It doesn’t matter what form of energy the black hole consumes, it will still grow. Interestingly, there’s a distinct possibility that black holes usually consume light.
